sentence: The initial rates of •OH reaction with RhB, H2O2, and silica or alumina were contrasted to assess the relative fate of •OH (Fig. 1).

In this analysis, conditions and parameter values were assumed and included an ideal representative volume of unconsolidated porous media (1 m3), 1 pore volume mixture of trichloroethylene (TCE) (10 mg/L) and H2O2 (10 g/L) with instantaneous mixing, no TCE sorption, and [•OH]SS = 5 × 10−16 mol/L (Fig. 2).
The rate of •OH reaction with solid surfaces (t = 0 h) dominated the fate of •OH by several orders of magnitude, relative to TCE and H2O2 in the aqueous phase (Fig. 2).

Conversely, in our study, •OH reaction was dominated by surface scavenging at 10–50 g/L silica, alumina, or MMT, in both Fe-AHP and UV-AHP systems (Fig. 1), and even greater •OH scavenging was projected under unconsolidated porous media conditions (Fig. 2).

The rate of •OH reaction with solid surfaces (t = 0 h) dominated the fate of •OH by several orders of magnitude, relative to TCE and H2O2 in the aqueous phase (Fig. 2).

Conversely, in our study, •OH reaction was dominated by surface scavenging at 10–50 g/L silica, alumina, or MMT, in both Fe-AHP and UV-AHP systems (Fig. 1), and even greater •OH scavenging was projected under unconsolidated porous media conditions (Fig. 2).
